TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit X509SecurityTokenParameters extends System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters

Docs.summary: Represents the parameters for an X.509 security token.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This class is a collection of token properties and methods, and is used in creating security binding elements and tokens.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.X509KeyIdentifierClauseType x509ReferenceStyle) cil managed

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks X509ReferenceStyle describes the kinds of security key identifier clauses that can be used to refer to the X509 security token. By default, references by `Thumbprint`, `IssuerSerial`, `SubjectKeyIdentifier`, and `RawDataKeyIdentifier` are accepted.
The following new instance property values are set to their defaults:
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.InclusionMode%2A> is set to <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.X509KeyIdentifierClauseType.Any>.
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.ReferenceStyle%2A> is set to <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenReferenceStyle.Internal>.
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.RequireDerivedKeys%2A> is set to `true`.
The corresponding properties are set to the values in the input parameters.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following new instance property values are set to their defaults:
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.InclusionMode%2A> is set to `inclusionMode`.
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.ReferenceStyle%2A> is set to `x509ReferenceStyle`.
- <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.RequireDerivedKeys%2A> is set to `true`.
The corresponding properties are set to the values in the input parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance class System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters CloneCore() cil managed
Protected Overrides Function CloneCore () As SecurityTokenParameters

Docs.summary: Clones another instance of this instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.Clone%2A> and <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.CloneCore%2A> methods follow the Core design pattern.
<xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenParameters.CloneCore%2A> is an `abstract` class which is overridden by <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.X509SecurityTokenParameters.CloneCore%2A>.
The <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.X509SecurityTokenParameters.CloneCore%2A> method calls the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.X509SecurityTokenParameters.%23ctor%2A> constructor.

.method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance class System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SecurityKeyIdentifierClause CreateKeyIdentifierClause(class System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SecurityToken token, valuetype System.ServiceModel.Security.Tokens.SecurityTokenReferenceStyle referenceStyle) cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates a key identifier clause for a token.

MemberSignature.Value: protected internal override bool HasAsymmetricKey { get; }
Protected Friend Overrides ReadOnly Property HasAsymmetricKey As Boolean
protected public: virtual property bool HasAsymmetricKey { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the token has an asymmetric key.
Docs.value: if the token has an asymmetric key; otherwise, . Always returns .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Asymmetric keys are used in public-key cryptography, which uses two keys, a public key and a private key, which are related mathematically. The public key is distributed widely, but the private key is kept secret. In public-key cryptography, there is no need to exchange a common key.

MemberSignature.Value: protected internal override void InitializeSecurityTokenRequirement (System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement requirement);
.method familyorassemblyhidebysig virtual instance void InitializeSecurityTokenRequirement(class System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement requirement) cil managed
Protected Friend Overrides Sub InitializeSecurityTokenRequirement (requirement As SecurityTokenRequirement)

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following properties of the <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement> are initialized:
- <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement.TokenType%2A> = <xref:System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SecurityTokenTypes.X509Certificate%2A>.
- <xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement.RequireCryptographicToken%2A> = `true`.
<xref:System.IdentityModel.Selectors.SecurityTokenRequirement.KeyType%2A> = <xref:System.IdentityModel.Tokens.SecurityKeyType.AsymmetricKey>.
